There can be few more prevalent indicators of 
the prevalent direction of wind in the South than the 
Sastrugi and yet, although there are marginal notes 
referring to them in the records and I have mentioned 
their importance in my Narrative, they are entirely 
neglected as evidence in this Volume. 
Many, if not all, of the reasons which created 
the general impression as t the local nature of our 
Easterly winds are given in the "Voyage of the Discovery", 
(for example Page 430, see also remarks quoted by Captain 
Hepworth page 423 Metl.Vol.) They have not been 
noticed by Dr Shaw. 
Therefore I submit to you that, in so far 
as Dr Shaw's remarks on "The Antarctic Anticyclone and 
Local Winds" encourage the belief that the prevalent 
surface winds of our region were Easterly, they are 
erroneous. 
The balance of evidence is strongly in favour 
of a prevalent Southerly and Westerly surface wind. 
Moreover for reasons which would unduly swell this letter I 
am of opinion that the balance of evidence does not show 
an increase of pressure to the Southward.
